title: 110_s2333
content: The "Health Care Safety Net Act of 2007" may be cited as the official title. This Act includes the Community Health Centers Program under the Public Health Service Act. The Health Centers Program of Public Health Service Act is authorized additional appropriations for fiscal years 2008 to 2012. This includes specific amounts allocated for each year to support community health centers. The term "community health center" refers to a health center receiving assistance under section 330 of the Public Health Service Act. The term "medically underserved population" has the same meaning as in section 330. A study on school-based health centers' economic costs and benefits, as well as their impact on students' health, will be conducted by the Comptroller General of the United States within 2 years of the Act's enactment. States shall analyze the impact of Federal funding on school-based health centers, cost savings to other Federal programs, potential budget and health effects of funding school-based health clinics, and the impact of health care access in rural or underserved areas. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in collaboration with other agencies, must submit a report to Congress within a year of this Act's enactment detailing efforts to enhance quality improvement in community health centers. The report will focus on federal initiatives in this area. The report to Congress, due within a year of the Act's enactment, will cover federal efforts on health care quality in community health centers, including data collection, analysis, and effective quality improvement models incorporating care coordination and disease management. The report to Congress will cover federal efforts on health care quality in community health centers, including improving access to providers through non-traditional means, targeting medically underserved populations, increasing access to specialty care, and enhancing the use of electronic health records to improve quality. Additionally, efforts will be made to adapt effective quality improvement models for implementation by community health centers. The report to Congress will cover federal efforts on health care quality in community health centers, including adapting effective quality improvement models for implementation by community health centers, varying by size, budget, staffing, services offered, populations served, and other characteristics determined appropriate by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Types of technical assistance and resources provided to facilitate quality improvement interventions will also be discussed, along with proposed or adopted methodologies for evaluations tailored to safety-net, community-based providers. The Health Resources and Services Administration will establish mechanisms for disseminating agency initiatives and best practices to support quality improvement efforts in community health centers. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on integrated health system models at 10 sites for delivering healthcare to medically underserved populations, focusing on models that integrate primary, specialty, and acute care. The Comptroller General of the United States will evaluate integrated health system models in rural and urban areas to expand access to primary and preventive services for medically underserved populations and improve care coordination and health outcomes. A report on the study will be submitted to Congress within 1 year of the enactment of the Act. The Comptroller General will evaluate integrated health system models in rural and urban areas to expand access to primary and preventive services for medically underserved populations. The assessment will include challenges faced by these entities and the advantages and disadvantages of these models compared to other care delivery models for underserved populations. The National Health Service Corps is addressed in Section 3. Funding for programs authorized under sections 331 through 338G of the Public Health Service Act is as follows: $131.5 million for 2008, $143.3 million for 2009, $156.2 million for 2010, $170.3 million for 2011, and $185.6 million for 2012. Amendments include eliminating the 6-year demonstration requirement and revising assignment to shortage areas. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include support for mentorship, professional development, and training opportunities for Corps members. The Secretary is required to assist Corps members in establishing professional relationships and development opportunities within the health professions community. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include support for mentorship, professional development, and training opportunities for Corps members. This includes establishing professional networks, mentorship linkages, and training modules to meet educational needs. Other professional development activities may also be provided at the discretion of the Secretary. The Secretary shall provide assistance in establishing relationships with hospitals, academic medical centers, health professions schools, area health education centers, health education and training centers, and border health education and training centers. This assistance includes help in obtaining faculty appointments at health professions schools. SEC. 4. REAUTHORIZATION OF RURAL HEALTH CARE PROGRAMS. Amends Section 330A(j) of the Public Health Service Act to increase funding to $45,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2008 through 2012.
